edu.rit.pj2

Class ObjectLoop<W>

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.pj2.LoopBody
      • edu.rit.pj2.ObjectLoop<W>
  • Type Parameters:
    W - Data type of the work items.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable

    public abstract class ObjectLoop<W>
extends LoopBody
    Class ObjectLoop is the abstract base class for a loop body executed by a parallel for loop over the work items in a WorkQueue.

    Programming pattern. To execute a parallel for loop over a series of work items in the main() method of a Task, follow this pattern: 

     public class MyTask extends Task
     {
     public void main (String[] args)
         {
         WorkQueue<W> queue = new WorkQueue<W>();
         queue.add (initial_work_item);
         parallelFor (queue) .exec (new ObjectLoop<W>()
             {
             // Thread-local variable declarations (optional)
             public void start()
                 {
                 // One-time thread-local initialization (optional method)
                 }
             public void run (W workitem)
                 {
                 // Loop body code for workitem (required method)
                 queue().add (another_work_item); // Optional
                 }
             public void finish()
                 {
                 // One-time thread-local finalization (optional method)
                 }
             });
         }
     }

    W is the data type of the work items. queue is a WorkQueue of work items to be processed in parallel. Call the work queue's add() method to add a work item to the work queue. Work items may be added to the work queue at any time by any thread; for example: by the task main thread before starting the parallel for loop; by a separate thread running concurrently with the parallel for loop; or in the parallel for loop body itself.

    Parallel thread team. The parallel for loop is executed by a team of threads. The number of threads is given by the threads property of the enclosing task (see the threads() method of class Task). The default is one thread for each core of the machine on which the program is running. The default can be overridden as follows: 

         parallelFor (queue) .threads (threads) .exec (new ObjectLoop<W>() ...

    Each thread operates on its own separate copy of the given ObjectLoop object. Each thread automatically creates its own copy by calling the clone() method on the given ObjectLoop object. Thus, any fields declared in the inner ObjectLoop subclass are thread-local variables, not shared variables. However, such fields must not be initialized as part of their declarations. Instead, such fields must be initialized in the start() method. If fields of the inner ObjectLoop subclass are initialized as part of their declarations, the cloning will not work properly.

    Each thread automatically does the following with its own loop object:

    • Call the start() method, once only. The start() method can contain one-time initialization code. Fields of the inner ObjectLoop subclass must be initialized in the start() method. If the start() method is not declared, the default is to do nothing.

    • Call the run() method zero or more times. On each call, a different work item from the work queue is passed in. The run() method must contain code to execute the loop body for the given workitem.

      For an object parallel for loop, the schedule and chunk properties are not used. Each thread repeatedly gets the next work item from the work queue and calls the run() method with that work item. The order in which the threads process the work items is not specified.

    • Call the finish() method, once only. The finish() method can contain one-time finalization code. If the finish() method is not declared, the default is to do nothing.

    Early loop exit. To terminate the parallel for loop before all the loop iterations have been executed, call the stop() method from inside the run() method. This causes all the threads in the team to stop calling the run() method (as soon as each thread's current iteration completes). Each thread in the team then proceeds to call the finish() method as described above.

    End-of-loop barrier. There is an implicit barrier at the end of the parallel for loop. After returning from the finish() method, each team thread arrives at the barrier. Once every team thread has arrived at the barrier, the exec() method returns.

    Reduction. To execute a parallel for loop with reduction, follow this pattern: 

     public class MyTask extends Task
     {
     IntVbl counter = new IntVbl.Sum();

     public void main (String[] args)
         {
         WorkQueue<W> queue = new WorkQueue<W>();
         parallelFor (queue) .exec (new ObjectLoop<W>()
             {
             IntVbl thrCounter;
             public void start()
                 {
                 thrCounter = threadLocal (counter);
                 }
             public void run (W obj)
                 {
                 if (. . .)
                     ++ thrCounter.item;
                 }
             });
         System.out.printf ("Counter = %d%n", counter.item);
         }
     }

    In this example, counter is declared as a field of the Task subclass, and so is a global shared variable. It is an instance of class IntVbl.Sum. The counter's item field is an integer. The counter's reduce() method adds the item fields together.

    thrCounter is declared as a field of the inner ObjectLoop subclass, and each team thread executing the loop gets its own copy of the loop, so each team thread gets its own separate thrCounter field. Note that the thrCounter field is not initialized as part of its declaration. When executing the loop, each team thread does the following:

    • Execute the start() method. Call the threadLocal() method, passing in the global counter. This returns a thread-local copy of the global counter, which becomes the thread's own thrCounter.

    • Execute the run() method multiple times. Increment the thread's own thrCounter's item field some number of times. Note that no synchronization is required, as each thread is updating its own thrCounter.

    When the loop finishes executing, all the threads' local variables are automatically reduced together in a multiple thread safe fashion. The reduction is performed by the reduce() method, so all the threads' local counters' item fields are added together. The result is stored back in the global variable's item field, which is then printed.

    See Also:
    ParallelStatement, ParallelForLoop, ObjectParallelForLoop, Schedule

    • Method Detail

      • run

        public abstract void run(W workitem)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Execute the loop body for the given work item.

        The run() method must be overridden in a subclass.

        Parameters:
        workitem - Work item.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - The run() method may throw any exception.

      • queue

        public WorkQueue<W> queue()
        Get the work queue from which this loop is obtaining work items.

        Work queue.
